facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 182 and 183 of 1954 filed under Article 132 of the Constitution from High Court judgment dated 17th November 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 182 and 183 of 1954. Appeals under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order, dated the 17th November, 1953, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in Civil Miscella

facts.text: Appeals connected to numerous Civil Miscellaneous Writs in Allahabad High Court from 1952 and 1953.
Appellants have been carrying on business of plying motor vehicles as stage carriages on Bulandshahr-Delhi route for a number of years.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in these two analogous appeals, along with many others, have been carrying on the business of plying motor vehicles, as ,stage carriages on hire, on the Bulandshabr-Delhi route from a number of years past.

facts.text: Running of vehicles regulated by Motor Vehicles Act of 1939, providing for permits by Regional Transport Authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The running of these vehicles has been regulated so long by the Motor Vehicles Act of 1939 which provides, inter alia, for granting of driving licences, the registration of vehicles and exercising companytrol over transport vehicles through permits granted by Regional Transport Authorities.

facts.text: Section 42(3) of Motor Vehicles Act exempts transport vehicles owned by Central or Provincial Government from permits unless connected with Indian State Railway business.

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 3  of the Act exempts transport vehicles, owned by or on behalf of the Central Government or the Provincial Government from the necessity of obtaining permits unless the vehicles were used in companynection Path the business of an Indian State Railway.

facts.text: After 1947, Government of U.P. started running buses as competitors to private operators, later decided to exclude private owners for complete State monopoly.

anchor.surface_text: It appears, that some time after 1947 the Government of U. P. companyceived the idea of running their own buses on the public thoroughfares. They first started running buses only as companypetitors with the private operators but later on they decided to exclude all private bus owners from the field and establish a companyplete State monopoly in respect to the road transport business.

facts.text: Transport Authorities cancelled permits of private operators and refused new ones to support State policy.

anchor.surface_text: The Transport Authorities, in furtherance of -this State policy, began cancelling the permits already issued to private operators and refusing permits to people who would otherwise have been entitled to them.

facts.text: Private bus owners filed writ petitions under Article 226 in Allahabad High Court against illegal use of Motor Vehicles Act by U.P. Government.

anchor.surface_text: Upon this, a number of private bus owners filed petitions in the Allahabad High Court under article 226 of the Constitution praying for appropriate relief, by way of writs, against what was described as the illegal use of the provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act -by the Government of U. P.

facts.text: Full Bench of five judges in Allahabad HC held that State exemption under s42(3) discriminates violating Article 14; nationalisation needs legislation under Art19(6).

anchor.surface_text: These petitions were heard by a Full Bench of five Judges and four judgments were delivered dealing with various questions that were raised by the parties. A majority of the judges expressed the opinion that the State, purporting to act under section 42 3  of the Motor Vehicles Act, companyld number discriminate against other persons in their own favour and that the sub- section, in so far as it purports to exempt State Transport buses from the obligation to obtain permits for their use, companyflicts with article 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: HC directed Transport Authorities to process private permit applications without influence of State monopoly policy.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this decision the Transport Authorities were directed to deal with the applications for permits, made by the various private bus owners, in accordance with the provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act, without in any way being influenced by the companysideration that the State Government wanted to run buses of their own on certain routes.

facts.text: U.P. Road Transport Act (Act II of 1951) passed and became law on 10th February 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this pronouncement of law, the State Government, which wanted to have the exclusive right to operate Road Transport Services within its territory, sought the assistance of the Legislature and the U. P. Road Transport Act  Act II of 1951  was passed and became law on and from the 10th of February, 1951.

facts.text: Preamble to U.P. Road Transport Act states it is expedient for general public and efficient road transport to provide State Road Transport Services.

anchor.surface_text: The preamble to the Road Transport Act  hereinafter called The Act  says Whereas it is expedient in the interest of the general public and for the promotion of the suitable and efficient road transport to provide -for a State Road Transport Services in Uttar Pradesh, it is enacted as follows.

facts.text: Section 3 of U.P. Road Transport Act allows State Government to declare exclusive or joint operation of road transport services if necessary for public interest.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3, which is the most material section in the Act, embodies virtually its whole purpose. It provides that where the State Government is satisfied that it is necessary, in the interest of general public and for sub- serving the companymon good, so to direct, it may declare that the Road Transport Services in general, or any particular class of such service on any route or portion thereof, shall be run and operated by the State Government exclusively or by the State Government in companyjunction with railway or partly by the State Government and partly by others in accordance with the provisions of this Act.

facts.text: Notification dated 25th March 1953 published declaration under s3 for exclusive State carriage services on Bulandshahr-Delhi route.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated the 25th of March, 1953, the U. Government published a declaration in terms of section 3 of the Act, to the effect, that the State carriage services, among others, on the Bulandshar Delhi route, shall be run and operated exclusively by the State Government.

facts.text: Notification on 7th April 1953 set out scheme for State carriage services on these routes.

anchor.surface_text: A further numberification issued on the 7th of April following set out what purported to be a scheme for the operation of the State carriage services on these routes.

facts.text: 106 private bus owners including two appellants filed writ petitions under Art226 before Allahabad HC for mandamus against interference with their operations.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the two appel- lants as well as several other private bus owners numbering 106 in all, who plied transport buses on these routes, presented petitions under article 226 of the Constitution before the High Court at Allahabad praying for writs, in the nature of mandamus, directing the U. P. Government and the State Transport Authorities number to interfere with the operation of the stage carriages of the petitioners and to refrain from operating the State Road Transport Service except in accordance with the provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act.

facts.text: Division Bench of Allahabad HC (Mukherji and Chaturvedi JJ) dismissed writ petitions on 17th November 1953.

anchor.surface_text: All these writ petitions were heard by a Division Bench of the High Court companysisting of Mukherji and Chaturvedi JJ. By two separate but companycurring judgments dated the 17th of November, 1953, the learned Judges repelled all the companytentions of the petitioners and dismissed the writ petitions.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 13, 1954 by Mukherjea J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. October 13. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUKHERJEA J.-

facts.text: Grand Trunk Road, including Bulandshahr-Delhi route, is a public highway existing since 15th Century A.D.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the Bulandshahr-Delhi route is a part of the Grand Trunk Road which is a public highway. ... There can be numberdispute that the Grand Trunk Road which, as a public highway, has been in existence since the 15th Century A. D.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds U.P. Road Transport Act 1951 violates Article 19(1)(g) as not reasonable restriction under clause 6 as it stood then, and Article 31(2) for no compensation.

anchor.surface_text: our companyclusion is that the legislation in question which violates the fundamental right of the appellants under article 19 1  g  of the Constitution and is number shown to be protected by clause  6  of the article, as it stood at the time of the enactment, must be held to be void under article 13 2  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Act does not violate Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that the appellant cannot make any grievance on this score and that the statute does number offend against article 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeals, sets aside High Court judgment, issues mandamus restraining enforcement of U.P. Road Transport Act 1951 against appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that in our opinion the appeals should be allowed and the judgment of the High Court set aside A writ in the nature of mandamus shall issue against the respondents in these appeals restraining them from enforcing the provisions of the U. P. State Road Transport Act, 1951, against the appellants or the men working under them.

holdings.text: The right of the public to ply motor vehicles on public highways for trade or business exists anterior to the Motor Vehicles Act as an incident of the public right of passage over highways and attracts the guarantee under Article 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: But the right of the public to use motor vehicles on the public road cannot, in any sense, be regarded as a right created by the Motor Vehicles Act. The right exists anterior to any legislation on this subject as an incident of public rights over a highway. The State only controls and regulates it for the purpose of ensuring safety, peace, health and good morals of the public. Once the position is accepted that a member of the public is entitled to ply motor vehicles on the public road as an incident of his right of passage over a highway, the question is really immaterial whether he plies a vehicle for pleasure or pastime or for the purpose of trade and business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Highway dedication implies right to all accustomed and similar modern traffic including motor vehicles for business; English law and Madras HC followed; rejects American franchise doctrine as inapplicable.

holdings.text: The U.P. Road Transport Act, 1951 violates Article 19(1)(g) and is not protected by Article 19(6) as it stood at enactment, hence void under Article 13(2).

anchor.surface_text: our conclusion is that the legislation in question which violates the fundamental right of the appellants under article 19 1 g of the Constitution and is number shown to be protected by clause 6 of the article, as it stood at the time of the enactment, must be held to be void under article 13 2 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act excludes private operators infringing 19(1)(g); no materials show reasonableness or public interest benefit; burden on state not discharged; directive principles and livelihood impact considered.

holdings.text: The Act deprives petitioners of their interest in a commercial undertaking, amounting to acquisition of property under Article 31(2) without compensation provision, rendering it invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We think therefore that in these circumstances the legislation does conflict with the provision of article 31 2 of the Constitution and as the requirements of that clause have number been companyplied with, it should be held to be invalid on that ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deprivation of business interest (intangible property) triggers 31(2); precedents like Subodh Gopal and Dwarkadas followed; mere prohibition vesting no right in state insufficient.

holdings.text: The Act does not violate Article 14 as classification favoring state monopoly is rational and bears reasonable relation to legislative object; Section 3 discretion regulated by Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that the appellant cannot make any grievance on this score and that the statute does number offend against article 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Monopoly inherently classifies state separately; rational nexus to welfare object; no unfettered discretion as permits under MV Act guide implementation; welfare state context.

holdings.text: The expression 'restriction' in Article 19(6) normally implies limitation short of total deprivation/prohibition, though may extend in some cases; no final opinion expressed.

anchor.surface_text: although in our opinion the normal use of the word restriction seems, to be in the sense of limitation and number extinction, we would on this occasion prefer number to express any final opinion on this matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary, precedents (Gopalan, Virgo), Excise case considered; prefers not to decide as unnecessary.

holdings.text: Article 301 issue not decided as unnecessary; observations on individual rights coverage and need for President's prior assent under 304(b) are tentative.

anchor.surface_text: we do number consider it necessary to record our decision on this point. We would only desire to indicate the contentions that have been or could be raised upon this point and the different views that are possible to be taken in respect to them

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act void on other grounds; indicates arguments from Australian precedent but no conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Packard v. Banton 1 , Sutherland J. observed as follows The streets belong to the public and are primarily for the use of the public in the ordinary way. Their use for purposes of gain is special and extraordinary and generally at least may be prohibited or condition

precedents.cited_proposition: Use of highways for purposes of gain is special and extraordinary use which the legislature may prohibit or condition
precedents.cited_holding: The streets belong to the public and are primarily for the use of the public in the ordinary way. Their use for purposes of gain is special and extraordinary and generally at least may be prohibited or conditioned as the Legislature deems proper.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was approved in Frost v. Railroad Commission 1 , and again in Stephenson v. Binford 3 , where Sutherland J. practically reiterated his observations in the previous case as follows It is a well established law that the highways of the State are public property that their primary

precedents.cited_proposition: Approval of doctrine that use for gain is special use on highways which legislature may condition or prohibit

anchor.surface_text: and again in Stephenson v. Binford 3 , where Sutherland J. practically reiterated his observations in the previous case as follows It is a well established law that the highways of the State are public property that their primary and preferred use is for private purposes and that their use for purposes of gain is special and extraordinary which generally at least the Legislature may prohibit or conditioned as it sees fit.

precedents.cited_proposition: Highways primary for private purposes, use for gain special and extraordinary which legislature may prohibit
precedents.cited_holding: It is a well established law that the highways of the State are public property that their primary and preferred use is for private purposes and that their use for purposes of gain is special and extraordinary which generally at least the Legislature may prohibit or condition as it sees fit.

anchor.surface_text: The cases referred to above were noticed by the Allahabad High Court in the Full Bench decision of Motilal v. Uttar Pradesh Government 1 , and two of the learned Judges constituting the Full Bench expressed their opinion that this doctrine of exceptional user might have been evolved by the American Courts in the same way as they evolved the doctrine of police powers.

precedents.cited_proposition: American doctrine of exceptional user for trade on highways does not embody English or Indian law

precedents.citation: C. S. S. Motor Service v. State of Madras 2

anchor.surface_text: This identical point was investigated with considerable thoroughness in a recent decision of the Madras High Court in C. S. S. Motor Service v. State of Madras 2 , and it was pointed out by Venkatarama Ayyar J. who delivered the judgment of the Court, that the rule of special or extraordinary use of highways in America had its roots in the doctrine of franchise,

precedents.case_name: C S S Motor Service v State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: State holds public roads as trustee for public; citizen entitled to use for transport business subject to regulations
precedents.cited_holding: The true position then is, that all public streets and roads vest in the State, but that the State holds them as trustees on behalf of the public. [...] the right of a citizen to carry on business in transport vehicles on public pathways cannot be denied to him on the ground that the State owns the highways.

precedents.citation: Municipal Corporation of the City of Toronto v. Virgo 1

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Municipal Corporation of the City of Toronto v. Virgo 1 , Lord Davey while discussing a statutory power conferred on a Municipal Council to make bye-laws for regulating and governing a trade made the following observation No doubt the regulation and governance of a trade may involve the imposition of restrictions on its exercise

precedents.case_name: Municipal Corporation of the City of Toronto v Virgo
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between prohibition of a trade and regulation or governance of it
precedents.cited_holding: there is a marked distinction to be drawn between the prohibition or prevention of a trade and the regulation or governance of it, and indeed a power to regulate and govern seems to imply the continued existence of that which is to be regulated or governed.

precedents.citation: A. K. Gopalan v. The State 2

anchor.surface_text: This line of reasoning receives support from the observations made by some of the learned Judges of this Court in their respective judgments in the case of A. K. Gopalan v. The State 2 . The question for consideration in that case was the constitutional validity of the Preventive Detention Act

precedents.case_name: A K Gopalan v The State
precedents.cited_proposition: Restrictions under Article 19 imply the rights are still capable of being exercised, presupposing substratum of freedom
precedents.cited_holding: The use of the word restrictions in the various sub- clauses seems to imply [...] that the rights guaranteed by the Article are still capable of being exercised, and to exclude the idea of incarceration

precedents.citation: Lokanath Misra v. The State of Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: The Orissa, High Court in the care of Lokanath Misra v. The State of Orissa 1 accepted this view and made a distinction between regulation and restriction. In the opinion of the learned Judges the observations of Lord Davey in Municipal Corporation of the City of Toronto v. Virgo supra

precedents.case_name: Lokanath Misra v The State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Restrictions can amount to deprivation; distinction between power to regulate and power to restrict

precedents.citation: Cooverjee v. The Excise COMMISSIONER, etc. 2

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents much reliance has also been placed on a decision of this Court in Cooverjee v. The Excise COMMISSIONER, etc. 2 where the point for consideration was the validity of the Excise Regulation I of 1915. It was contended, inter alia, on behalf of the appellant in that case

precedents.cited_proposition: Reasonable restrictions under Article 19(6) may include prohibition of certain trades like liquor
precedents.cited_holding: Laws prohibiting trades in noxious or dangerous goods or trafficking in women cannot be held to be illegal as enacting a prohibition and not a mere regulation.

precedents.citation: Commonwealth of Australia and Others v. Bank of New South Wales and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: As a proposition of law, the first ground may not admit of any dispute but we think that the observations of Lord Porter in the Privy Council case of Commonwealth of Australia and Others v. Bank of New South Wales and Others 1 upon which considerable reliance has been placed by the High Court would indicate the proper way of approach to this question

precedents.case_name: Commonwealth of Australia v Bank of New South Wales
precedents.cited_proposition: Prohibition with view to State monopoly not per se unreasonable; must be judged on facts, time and circumstances
precedents.cited_holding: in no circumstances could the exclusion of competition so as to create a monopoly [...] be justified. Every case must be judged on its own facts and in its own setting of time and circumstance

precedents.citation: Gooverjee v. The Excise, Commissioner, etc. 1

anchor.surface_text: As has been held by this Court in the case of Gooverjee v. The Excise, Commissioner, etc. 1 whether the restrictions are reasonable or not would depend to a large extent on the nature of the trade and the conditions prevalent in it.

precedents.cited_proposition: Whether restrictions reasonable depends on nature of business and conditions prevailing in that trade

precedents.citation: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: This argument, we think, is not tenable having regard to the majority decision of this Court in the case of State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose and Others 1 and Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. The Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. 2 .

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: Articles 31(1) and 31(2) are not mutually exclusive but read together; deprivation under (1) means acquisition under (2)

precedents.citation: Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. The Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. 2

precedents.case_name: Dwarkadas Shrinivas v Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Articles 31(1) and 31(2) to be read together as dealing with protection of property

precedents.cited_proposition: State when carrying on trade occupies same position as private traders and acts not sovereign

anchor.surface_text: it has been definitely held by the Judicial Committee in the case of Commonwealth of Australia v. The Bank of New South Wales supra , that the rights of individuals do come within the purview of the section.

precedents.cited_proposition: Rights of individuals come within purview of freedom of trade provisions; citizens can resist legislative actions offending it
precedents.cited_holding: section 92 does not create any new juristic rights but it does give the citizens [...] the right to ignore and, if necessary, to call on the judicial power to help him to resist legislative- or executive actions which offend against the section.
